Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Response of Carbon Accumulation in Moss Peatbanks to Past Warm Climates in the Antarctic Peninsula
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
This research will investigate how Antarctic peatbanks have responded to documented past warm climates on the Western Antarctic Peninsula over the last 1000 years. The work will extend understanding of climate controls on peat carbon accumulation to Antarctic peatbanks thus enabling a bi-polar perspective of ?first responder? ecosystem processes under warmer climate conditions. Understanding climate and ecosystem histories will help reveal processes and mechanisms that control the functioning of these and other polar ecosystems. Specifically, the investigators will evaluate outcomes of ?natural climate-warming experiments? that have occurred in the AP region at 65 degrees south over the last 1000 years. They will focus on two warm climate intervals in the Western Antarctic Peninsula: (1) the recent and ongoing warming of up to 6Â°C in the last century, and (2) the Medieval Warm Period that occurred ~800 years ago. By collecting and analyzing peat cores and other biological and environmental data, the investigators will derive an independent temperature reconstruction from oxygen isotopes of moss cellulose over the last 1000 years to assess peatbank carbon response to documented warm climate conditions. The overall goal of the proposed project is to document formation ages and temporal changes in carbon-accumulating ecosystems over the last millennium in response to climate change as reconstructed from independent proxies. Also, their data will allow the investigators to understand the nature of reconstructed climate change in relation to atmosphere circulation and ocean conditions.

Broader impacts:
This research is directly relevant to understanding polar processes affecting soil carbon dynamics and will support an early career researcher. This project will provide training for undergraduate students, graduate student and a postdoctoral fellow and will develop teaching modules and outreach activities on polar climate and ecosystem changes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Amplification of global warming at the poles — that is, faster than average rates of climate change in the Arctic and the Antarctic — has long been recognized as a characteristic pattern of past and recent Earth System behavior. The western Antarctic Peninsula has experienced some of the fastest warming conditions globally during recent decades, with associated rapid changes in cryosphere and biosphere. The greenest ice-free coastal regions are dominated by bryophytes that can form aerobic peatbanks and accumulate plant carbon over time. In this pilot project, we collected and analyzed plants and peat cores from several sites along the western Antarctic Peninsula. Our goal was to better understand long-term patterns of carbon storage and ecosystem changes on the Peninsula relevant to plant growth and carbon sequestration during recent decades in the context of the last three thousand years. This investigation was a collaborative project that consisted of research teams from the University of Hawaii and Lehigh University.

In the austral summer of 2014, we conducted fieldwork on the Antarctic Peninsula during cruise G-094-P. We collected plant samples and peat cores from several sites along the Peninsula and conducted detailed studies in the regions around Palmer Station and Vernadsky Base (in collaboration with the National Academy of Science of Ukraine), including the monitoring of local microclimate. Significantly, we were able to opportunistically sample farther north (64° S) and south (67° S) than planned originally. Additionally, we found new ‘black moss’ sites of re-exposed organic matter following ice retreat that has allowed us to date the timing of past ice advances. We also documented that ice-free conditions were widespread along the central Peninsula earlier than previously thought by several centuries. Careful carbon measurements allowed us to quantify carbon storage in these unique ecosystems. In addition, by studying the species-specific isotope geochemistry of modern plants and specific chemical compounds extracted from subfossil plant tissues, we found that plant growth conditions have been highly variable on multi-decadal scales, and that discrimination by dominant plants during recent decades has been higher than any time during the previous two thousand years. Recent rates of organic accumulation in peatbanks was revealed to be surprisingly fast at some sites, similar to rates much further north in sub-antarctic regions.

The results from this pilot project point to a hypothesis that environmental change is surprisingly abrupt in the terrestrial environment of the coastal Antarctic Peninsula, and that regional change evident in glacial-ice cores and marine sediments may be amplified in the land environment. This pilot project provided a partial view of the processes affecting this rapidly-changing polar environment, and point to gaps in data and understanding that can be addressed with additional collections and monitoring. An implication of this work is that future response of terrestrial ecosystems is likely to be rapid and widespread, based on the documented sensitivity to past natural and anthropogenic climate change. Peer-reviewed papers have been published and continue to be submitted, and several presentations at national and international meetings have been made. At the University of Hawaii, a graduate student and two undergraduates received training, all women, and these have continued in science-based careers and graduate studies. The results of this research continues to be incorporated into classroom teaching in the form of case studies and physical samples for student research projects, and outreach continues to be conducted, particularly with K-12 and organizations targeting young people.
